tn.text: This refers to Nebuchadnezzar and his soldiers, not only to Nebuchadnezzar. AT: "Nebuchadnezzar's soldiers" or "Nebuchadnezzar king of Babylonia and his soldiers" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])

tn.ref: to cut off all supplies to it
tn.text: "to stop the people from receiving any supplies"
This refers to Jehoiakim and his soldiers, not only to Jehoiakim. AT: "the army of Jehoiakim king of Judah" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
Jehoiakim gave Nebuchadnezzar
Although Nebuchadnezzar did not do these things alone, it may easier for the reader to retain the singular pronouns. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
Here "them" probably refers to Jehoiakim and other prisoners, as well as the sacred objects.
This was an act of devotion to his god.
This refers to Nebuchadnezzar.
This is the chief official. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
This is the highest social class.
These two negative words together emphasize a positive idea. AT: "with perfect appearance" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_litotes]])
This is an idiom. This means they knew much and could organize and use that information. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
This is the large house or building where the king lives.
"Ashpenaz was to teach them"

tn.ref: The king counted out for them
tn.text: The king's officials did this task for him. AT: "The king's officials counted out for them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
the special, rare, good foods that the king ate

tn.ref: These young men were to be trained
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "Ashpenaz was to train these young men" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
"taught skills"
"Among the young men from Israel"
This refers to Ashpenaz who was King Nebuchadnezzar's highest official.
These are all men's names. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
Here "mind" refers to Daniel himself. AT: "Daniel decided to himself" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])

To "pollute" something is to make is unclean. Some of the food and drink of the Babylonians would make Daniel ceremonially unclean according to God's law. This can be made explicit. AT: "make himself unclean according to God's law" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
This refers to the special, rare, good foods that the king ate. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:dan:01:01|1:3]].

tn.ref: Why should he see you looking worse than the other young men of your own age?
tn.text: The official uses this question to explain what he thought would happen. It can be a statement. AT: "He does not want to see you looking worse than the other young men of your own age." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

tn.ref: The king might have my head
tn.text: This is an idiom. AT: "The king might cut off my head" or "The king might kill me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

tn.ref: compare our appearance with the appearance
tn.text: Daniel asked the steward to see if he and his friends looked worse than the other young men. AT:"compare our appearance to see if it is worse than the appearance"

tn.ref: tested them ... their appearance ... they were ... their delicacies ... their wine
tn.text: All of these pronouns refer to Daniel, Hananiah, Mishael, and Azariah.
This means to have been made healthy from what you have eaten.

tn.ref: God gave them knowledge and insight
tn.text: This can be reworded so that the abstract nouns "knowledge" and "insight" can be expressed as the verbs "learn" and "understand." AT: "God gave them the ability to learn and understand clearly in" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
This is an exaggeration to show that they had a very good education and understanding. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_hyperbole]])
The king spoke with the "four young men" ([[:en:bible:notes:dan:01:17|1:17]]).

tn.ref: among the whole group there were none to compare with Daniel, Hananiah, Mishael, and Azariah
tn.text: This can be stated in positive form. AT: "Daniel, Hananiah, Mishael, and Azariah pleased him much more than anyone else in the whole group" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_litotes]])
These are the names of men. See how you translated these names in [[:en:bible:notes:dan:01:06|1:6-7]].
Here "ten times" is an exaggeration representing great quality. AT: "much better" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_hyperbole]])

tn.ref: the first year of King Cyrus
tn.text: "the first year that King Cyrus ruled Babylon"
